post_text:
Fall sports have kicked off this week. If you’re planning to attend tonight’s football scrimmage at Panther Stadium, remember to bring a facial covering in order to enter the venue.

To keep our community safe, spectators will be asked to social distance. Go to www.sheldonisd.com to learn how we are preparing to keep our athletes and spectators safe in the stands. Click the banner across the website that says Fall Sports Update.

post_text:
Good morning. Today marks the 19th anniversary of the 9-11-01 terrorist attacks in our country - most notably the World Trade Center in New York and the Pentagon in Washington, DC.

It was estimated that nearly 3,000 innocent Americans lost their lives that day.

Gone - but not forgotten!

#sheldonstrong

post_text:
Good morning, and welcome to the beginning of the 2020-2021 school year!

Just a reminder....There are multiple ways to access Google Classroom:
1. Access the new MyLink portal (www.sheldonisd.com --> Parents --> MyLink)
2. Visit Sheldon ON Demand (www.sheldonondemand.com) and follow the prompts
3. Access Google Classroom directly at classroom.google.com

Please remember - you MUST be logged in with a valid Sheldon ISD email account.

If you are having issues with accessing any of the above, please contact our Sheldon ISD Helpdesk by emailing helpdesk@apps.sheldonisd.com or by calling 832-460-5005 (please save this number in your contact list) Monday through Friday from 8 a.m. to 4 p.m.

Also, please send us your First Day of School photos at #sheldonstartsstrong!

post_text:
Harris County Precinct 2 Commissioner Adrian Garcia is proud to announce the North Shore Pavilion Study Area with FREE WIFI for the Community. Students and their parents are welcome study and take their virtual classes at the North Shore Pavilion at 14350 1/2 Wallisville Rd, Houston, Texas 77049 from 8:00 am until 6:00 pm, Monday through Friday until December 14, 2020!

Starting Tuesday, September 1, 2020 and every Tuesday until December 14, 2020 the Harris County Public Library will provide their Ecard Creation, Digital Material Assistance, Book Give Away services for everyone at the Pavilion. Registration is required to enter the Precinct 2 Study Area.

post_text:
Unfortunately, we experienced a privacy setting issue this morning during our live parent training. One of the attendees had posted inappropriate comments in the chat feature of Zoom
(this is often referred to as ‘zoom bombing’). We have quickly worked to correct this Zoom setting so this will not be a concern in future meetings. Please be assured when classes begin virtually this fall, students enrolled in the classes will be given login information that is not made public. Unlike classes for our students, these parent trainings are made public so that we can reach as many parents as possible to assist as they prepare. We apologize for any offense this morning’s Zoom webinar may have caused, but we are thankful that we were able to quickly make adjustments to ensure our privacy for future meetings.
text:

Please be assured when classes begin virtually this fall, students enrolled in the classes will be given login information that is not made public. Unlike classes for our students, these parent trainings are made public so that we can reach as many parents as possible to assist as they prepare. We apologize for any offense this morning’s Zoom webinar may have caused, but we are thankful that we were able to quickly make adjustments to ensure our privacy for future meetings.

post_text:
KHS Students and Parents,

Dual Credit Technical Classes (Hands-on-Hybrid) begin August 24

Dual Credit Technical students should review the schedule of when specific technical courses are held in person. Students should check their San Jac Blackboard accounts for when they are to login for online instruction. For questions about registration and classes, students should email Tunisia Wolridge or call 409-241-0279. For questions about bus pickup times and locations, call the Transportation Department at 281-727-1400. SISD personnel will be in front of the San Jac buildings on August 24 to direct students to their classes.

post_text:
C. E. King Volleyball Tryout Information

Tryouts will be on Monday August 17th and Tuesday August 18th for all students interested in being a part of the volleyball program at C. E. King High School. Players will attend 2 time sessions based on their age, and are expected to come to tryout on both days. See attached document for specific times based on student grade level.
Students that are not able to attend the tryout, or that have additional questions contact Coach M at AmandaMurphy@sheldonisd.com
Teams will be announced at the end of the last tryout, and posted on the volleyball website on 8/18 by 5:00pm.
text:
C. E. King Volleyball Tryout Information

Tryouts will be on Monday August 17th and Tuesday August 18th for all students interested in being a part of the volleyball program at C. E. King High School. Players will attend 2 time sessions based on their age, and are expected to come to tryout on both days. See attached document for specific times based on student grade level.
Students that are not able to attend the tryout, or that have additional questions contact Coach M at AmandaMurphy@sheldonisd.com
Teams will be announced at the end of the last tryout, and posted on the volleyball website on 8/18 by 5:00pm.

post_text:
Over the next decade, lawmakers, business owners, and many others will use 2020 Census data to make critical decisions. The results will show where communities need new schools, new clinics, new roads, and more services for families, older adults, and children.
The results will also inform how hundreds of billions of dollars in federal funding are allocated to more than 100 programs, including Medicaid, Head Start, block grants for community mental health services, and the Supplemental Nutrition Assistance Program, also known as SNAP.
[On average the 2020 Census takes about 10 minutes to complete. To fill out an online census form today, please visit https://2020census.gov.]

FACTS:
The 2020 Census will provide a snapshot of our nation—who we are, where we live, and so much more.
The results of this once-a-decade count determine the number of seats each state has in the House of Representatives. They are also used to draw congressional and state legislative districts.
[On average the 2020 Census takes about 10 minutes to complete. To fill out an online census form today, please visit https://2020census.gov.]

In light of this morning's new executive order by Harris County Judge Lina Hidalgo, Sheldon ISD has suspended - until further notice - all student and/or staff activities (including athletic summer workouts) that fall under the "gatherings in excess of 100 people" protocol.

The does not include tomorrow's KHS Graduation Ceremony - as this event may continue because it falls under previous guidelines set forth by the Texas Education Agency.
text:
In light of this morning's new executive order by Harris County Judge Lina Hidalgo, Sheldon ISD has suspended - until further notice - all student and/or staff activities (including athletic summer workouts) that fall under the "gatherings in excess of 100 people" protocol.

The does not include tomorrow's KHS Graduation Ceremony - as this event may continue because it falls under previous guidelines set forth by the Texas Education Agency.

post_text:
6/26/20 | 1:25 p.m.

C. E. King Senior Class of 2020, Parents and Sheldon ISD Community:

Sheldon ISD administrators received confirmation earlier this afternoon from Harris County Judge Lina Hidalgo’s office that the district may move forward with Saturday’s Graduation Ceremony at Sheldon ISD Panther Stadium because this event falls within the previously established health protocols issued by the Texas Education Agency.

However, due to Judge Hidalgo’s recent Stay-at-Home Order as of this morning, tonight’s Senior Send-Off Parade must be cancelled because this event does not fall within TEA-approved guidelines.

Lastly, please remember that everyone in attendance at tomorrow's KHS Graduation Ceremony must wear face coverings – and must comply with social distancing guidelines.

Thank you.
text:
6/26/20 | 1:25 p.m.

C. E. King Senior Class of 2020, Parents and Sheldon ISD Community:

Sheldon ISD administrators received confirmation earlier this afternoon from Harris County Judge Lina Hidalgo’s office that the district may move forward with Saturday’s Graduation Ceremony at Sheldon ISD Panther Stadium because this event falls within the previously established health protocols issued by the Texas Education Agency.

However, due to Judge Hidalgo’s recent Stay-at-Home Order as of this morning, tonight’s Senior Send-Off Parade must be cancelled because this event does not fall within TEA-approved guidelines.

Lastly, please remember that everyone in attendance at tomorrow's KHS Graduation Ceremony must wear face coverings – and must comply with social distancing guidelines.

Thank you.

post_text:
6/25/20 - Important Information About Upcoming Senior Parade, Graduation

C. E. King High School Senior Class of 2020 and Parents,

Please be aware that all individuals who plan on attending Friday’s Senior Parade or Saturday’s Graduation will be required to wear face coverings, according to a recent executive order issued by Harris County. Also, district administrators are continuing to closely monitor the weather as well as any potential new orders developing from the governor’s office regarding outdoor crowd sizes that could impact this weekend’s planned events.

Lastly, as we are still moving forward as scheduled, graduation ticket packets may be picked up tomorrow, June 26, from 5 p.m. to 7 p.m. at the Sheldon ISD Panther Stadium ticket window located on the home side.

For the latest information, please continue to follow us on this social media page.

Sheldon Community,

🚨The Harris County COVID-19 Relief Fund public application is now open!🚨

You can apply online at www.harriscountyrelief.org or over the phone at (832) 848-0214.

The PHONE application will close today (June 23) at 2PM CT and will open back up tomorrow (June 24) at 2PM CT, but you can apply ONLINE anytime before 10PM CT tomorrow (June 24).

**This is not a first come, first serve process.**

If calling by phone, friendly operators will help applicants during the process by recording their answers and submitting the application.

Application Dates/Times
June 23: Open 6AM – 2PM CT
June 24: Open 2PM – 10PM CT

Applications will not be accepted at the Greater Houston Community Foundation.

For additional information about the application process, please visit www.harriscountyrelief.org.

Thank you, EHCEC - East Harris County Empowerment Council for helping spread the word!

post_text:
FACTS:
Will the 2020 Census be available in languages other than English?
By eliminating the guesswork in how many translated forms to print and mail, the internet response option makes it easier to provide census materials in multiple languages. The 2020 Census Internet Self-Response Instrument and questionnaire assistance will be available in 12 non-English languages (Arabic, Chinese, French, Haitian Creole, Japanese, Korean, Polish, Portuguese, Russian, Spanish, Tagalog, and Vietnamese). Bilingual (English and Spanish) materials will include enumerator instruments, paper questionnaires, mailings, and field enumeration. In addition, language guides, language glossaries, and language identification cards will be available in 59 non-English languages.
[On average the 2020 Census takes about 10 minutes to complete. To fill out an online census form today, please visit https://2020census.gov.]

post_text:
Important Information About Graduation Tickets from C. E. King High School Administration

Dear Senior Class of 2020 Students and Parents,

Due to COVID-19, we are required to social distance each family during our graduation ceremony. With that being said, each family will receive four non-transferable tickets with the students' names and seating sections. For example: Student A only needs 2 tickets and wants to give/sell to student B who needs 2 more tickets. Because of social distancing, the two tickets from student A would require the users of those tickets to sit with Student A’s family. We are social distancing families based on state standards for graduation. Each student will also receive 2 parking passes. Each car entering the parking lot will have to have a parking ticket including graduates who drive.

Communication was sent out asking if students would be participating in graduation. If you or your student answered NO, tickets will not be provided to you. We are committed to the safety of our students and guests.
text:
Important Information About Graduation Tickets from C. E. King High School Administration

Dear Senior Class of 2020 Students and Parents,

Due to COVID-19, we are required to social distance each family during our graduation ceremony. With that being said, each family will receive four non-transferable tickets with the students' names and seating sections. For example: Student A only needs 2 tickets and wants to give/sell to student B who needs 2 more tickets. Because of social distancing, the two tickets from student A would require the users of those tickets to sit with Student A’s family. We are social distancing families based on state standards for graduation. Each student will also receive 2 parking passes. Each car entering the parking lot will have to have a parking ticket including graduates who drive.

Communication was sent out asking if students would be participating in graduation. If you or your student answered NO, tickets will not be provided to you. We are committed to the safety of our students and guests.

post_text:
FACTS:
Where does the Census Bureau count people who have more than one home?
People with seasonal homes or who have transitory living arrangements (such as RV parks, carnivals) are counted at the residence where they live and sleep most of the time. If they have no usual residence, they’re counted at their location on Census Day.
[On average the 2020 Census takes about 10 minutes to complete. To fill out an online census form today, please visit https://2020census.gov.]

post_text:
Sheldon Community,

In partnership with the Mayor's Office of Education with the City of Houston and Microsoft, Sheldon ISD would like to share some information with you regarding an upcoming Virtual Symposium on Digital Technology Careers that is taking place on June 22-23.

This virtual symposium is open for those participants between the ages of 18-26 with an interest in digital technology careers.

Each day will be filled with workshops focused on: online learning and virtual collaboration; Post-COVID career opportunities in digital technology; emerging technologies in industry and society; and pathways to industry and higher education.

Please see the attached PDF file for additional information - including how to sign up for this virtual event.

post_text:
Where does the Census Bureau count people who have more than one home?
U.S. military personnel assigned to military vessels with a U.S. homeport on Census Day are counted at the onshore residence where they live and sleep most of the time. If they have no onshore residence, they’re counted at their vessel’s homeport.
[On average the 2020 Census takes about 10 minutes to complete. To fill out an online census form today, please visit https://2020census.gov.]

post_text:
District meal distributions are changing to four days a week beginning June 15

Dear Sheldon ISD Community,

Beginning Monday, June 15, Sheldon ISD will be changing its curbside meal distribution schedule to four days a week (Monday through Thursday) from 9 a.m. to 11 a.m. at the same five campus locations: C. E. King Middle School Null Middle School, Carroll Elementary, Royalwood Elementary, and Sheldon Elementary.

Please continue to practice social distancing, and have a wonderful summer!

post_text:
Summer Workouts will begin on Monday, June 8 for incoming 7th-12th grade girls. All female athletes park or get dropped off in front of the Competition Gym. (Parents please remain in your vehicle.)

We are asking all athletes to wear a mask during the check-in process and to remain in designated marked spots until instructed to move forward.

You will need to bring your own water bottle and towel. No bags allowed. Make sure you bring your cell phone to check in.

Please arrive between 7:30 a.m. - 7:45 a.m. Workouts will go from 8 a.m. - 10 a.m. We will be sending home more information on Monday after we have orientation with the student-athletes.

If you have any questions, please contact Coach Rhoads at tawanarhoads@apps.sheldondisd.com

Parents, as we plan for the 2020-2021 school year, we would like your feedback regarding your child’s learning environment.
This survey, which takes fewer than three minutes, may be found by clicking on the link below - or by visiting the following URL: www.sheldonisd.com/survey/. The deadline to complete the parent survey is Thursday, June 18.

CLARIFICATION INFORMATION:
We would like for parents to know that they are not giving a final decision on their preference...we just need preliminary numbers now to begin planning. However, when we get closer to the beginning of the 2020-2021 school year, parents will then have an opportunity to inform the district of their final decision. Thank you.

post_text:
The online application for the Pandemic Electronic Benefit Transfer (P-EBT) is now open for eligible families at yourtexasbenefits.com/Learn/PEBT (URL is case-sensitive).

------

Pandemic Electronic Benefit Transfer (P-EBT) is a one-time food benefit for families who lost access to free or reduced-priced meals due to school closures. The EBT application will open the first week of June.

P-EBT food benefits are for children who received SNAP food benefits for March 2020 and children who are certified for free or reduced-priced school meals during the 2019-20 school year.

For Frequently-Asked Questions, please visit: https://hhs.texas.gov/services/health/coronavirus-covid-19/coronavirus-covid-19-information-texans/pandemic-ebt-p-ebt-due-covid-19

post_text:
REMINDER:

Sheldon ISD has scheduled June 1-2 as designated days for students to pick up personal belongings and/or drop off school-issued supplies – such as textbooks, library books, technology devices, etc.

Here are the scheduled times for the designated pick-up days: June 1 will be 7:30 a.m. to 2:30 p.m.; and June 2 will be 11:30 a.m. to 6:30 p.m.

Also, to remain in compliance with Gov. Greg Abbott’s executive orders, school buildings will remain closed to the public. However, designated drive-through lines have been established at each campus – and we are asking parents to please display a car rider sign…or a homemade sign…including ALL names of those students whose items you’ll be picking up. Parents, you will also need to remain in your cars while helpers gather personal items to load for you.

Secondary students who need to return uniforms or other program-specific items will be contacted by their coaches or sponsors as to how to return these items.

Where does the Census Bureau count people who have more than one home?
College students who live in college/university student housing are counted at the student housing rather than at their parents’ or guardians’ homes.
[On average the 2020 Census takes about 10 minutes to complete. To fill out an online census form today, please visit https://2020census.gov.]

5/29/20 | 11:50 a.m.
Approximately 18 students - representing a portion of the "C" alphabet - were inadvertently left off of the main C. E. King High School Class of 2020 Virtual Graduation video. Once our third party vendor was made aware of this error, they immediately sent us this video with the missing individuals.

Sheldon ISD is very sorry for any inconveniences this may have caused to our seniors and their families.

Please continue to check back on the graduation page (www.sheldonisd.com/graduation/) in the coming days - as we will take this video and incorporate it into the main virtual graduation video for everyone to enjoy!

Thank you for your understanding.

https://youtu.be/agiQoJWf7po

post_text:
Dear Sheldon Community,

As a source of community pride, Sheldon ISD will be displaying tonight's "C. E. King High School Class of 2020 Virtual Graduation" on the giant video board at the new Sheldon ISD Panther Stadium.

The video will play at approximately 7 p.m.

Rules/Guidelines
Due to our current social distancing guidelines under the executive order by Gov. Greg Abbott, no one will be allowed inside Sheldon ISD Panther Stadium. This means there will be no restrooms and/or concessions available, so please plan accordingly.

Also, individuals may bring lawn chairs, blankets, or even remain in their vehicles in order to be as comfortable as possible - but you MUST maintain social distancing, as required by law.

One suggested viewing area is the upper portion of the north end of the stadium. There is a great view of the video board, and the sound should also be sufficient.

Lastly, for those who would like to view the video in the comfort of their own homes, the same video will be posted at approximately 7 p.m. by visiting the following URL: www.sheldonisd.com/graduation/

#SHELDONSTRONG

post_text:
How does the Census Bureau know where people live?
To count every person, the Census Bureau relies on an accurate and up-to-date list of residential addresses. This list is known as the Master Address File, and includes addresses served by the U.S. Postal Service, information gathered from local governments, and information updated by Census Bureau employees in the field.
[On average the 2020 Census takes about 10 minutes to complete. To fill out an online census form today, please visit https://2020census.gov.]

Pandemic Electronic Benefit Transfer (P-EBT) is a one-time food benefit for families who lost access to free or reduced-priced meals due to school closures. The EBT application will open the first week of June.

P-EBT food benefits are for children who received SNAP food benefits for March 2020 and children who are certified for free or reduced-priced school meals during the 2019-20 school year.

For Frequently-Asked Questions, please visit: https://hhs.texas.gov/services/health/coronavirus-covid-19/coronavirus-covid-19-information-texans/pandemic-ebt-p-ebt-due-covid-19

post_text:
Day 30 of mental health tips

Staying focused when Distracted by stress is a task that is practiced by setting realistic goals. Signs you are stressed:
Dizziness or a general feeling of "being out of it."
General aches and pains.
Grinding teeth, clenched jaw.
Headaches.
Increase in or loss of appetite

Coping strategies to stay focused:
-Focus on one thing at a time.
Exercise
-Ask for Help
- Try not to overthink what should happen

Appointment letters were mailed out on May 8th. Please be on time to your appointment so that you can walk across the stage and take your photograph. King High School website under Seniors - Class of 2020 and social media for all Senior information.

post_text:
Sheldon ISD parents,

San Jacinto College is now accepting applications for its NASA "Pathway to the Stars" free online summer camp for students who just completed grades 5-8.

More information and registration forms (English and Spanish): https://www.sanjac.edu/pathway-to-the-stars-camp

ABOUT THE CAMP
FREE STEM Summer camps - These FREE two week-long cyber camps are for students who have just completed the 5th, 6th, 7th and 8th grades as of May 2020. These online camps are offered in 2-week formats for 4 hours of student engagement per day (Monday to Friday). Camp topics focus on NASA’s journey to MARS and include the engineering design cycle, rocketry, parachute landings, survival systems, space weather, navigation, robotics, and more... These summer camps will be offered online but limited to Texas residents only. Please use the packet below to register your students now and return registration to aerospace@sjcd.edu.

San Jacinto College

post_text:
Day 27 of mental health tips

Set up contingencies ahead of time Everyone works better when they know and understand the expectations ahead of time.
Create routines. Routines give a sense of stability to children and teens, especially those who struggle with anxiety.

Routines can help children understand time and time management. Routines can help children get used to having chores. Routines can strengthen relationships by focusing on time together

Are census responses confidential?
The confidentiality of census records is protected by Title 13 of the U.S. Code. No data or tabulation may be produced that could be used to identify an individual. Individual records may not be released for at least 72 years.
[On average the 2020 Census takes about 10 minutes to complete. To fill out an online census form today, please visit https://2020census.gov.]

post_text:
Day 26 of mental health tips

Intrusive Thoughts-They are unwanted thoughts or images that pop into our head without reason and can cause you to become obsessed or distressed.
Break down problem thoughts and bring your child back to reality. Talking about what is worrying them will help normalize the feelings

Focus on what you can do.
By focusing on what is in your control and what you can do, you allow yourself to be in charge.

Day 25 of mental health tips

Praise successes and use setbacks as learning opportunities. Help them to help themselves.
It’s great for your child in the long-term to learn about their feelings and it will also create strong coping skills.
Ask questions like, “What can you do the next time you’re in this situation?” or “What made you feel better the last time you felt this way?”

post_text:
Day 24 of mental health tips

Building Resilience takes time. A child in crisis and out of control cannot rely on reason
Create calm. Your gut reaction may be to panic that our children look to us to model the best ways to remain calm or create calmness.

Soften your voice and use short, clear directions:
“Come with me.” “ Let's sit together.” “Take a deep breath.” “ Can you tell me what’s going on?

post_text:
Will the Census Bureau keep coming to my door if I don’t fill out my 2020 Census form?
If you don’t respond to the 2020 Census, the Census Bureau will send up to five mailings to your address and an enumerator to your door. For up to six days (with the possibility of more than one contact attempt per day), an enumerator will attempt to gather census information from someone in the household. After each contact attempt, the enumerator will leave a “Notice of Visit” form encouraging households to respond via mail, phone, or online. After three days of attempting to contact someone at the address, an enumerator may begin contacting neighbors to request a proxy response for the nonresponding household.
[On average the 2020 Census takes about 10 minutes to complete. To fill out an online census form today, please visit https://2020census.gov.]

post_text:
Day 23 of mental health tips

Create rules for the home. Develop a set of basic, simple and straightforward household rules.
Timing is everything.In stressful situations, allow your child some space and address issues later when they have regained control
Helpful statements to say when emotions are calm:
-This is hard I understand
-It’s normal to feel scared
-How can we solve the problem together

post_text:
Day 22 of mental health tips

Encourage communication. Let your child know that they can talk to you about their thoughts, feelings, or difficult situations they’re dealing with.
When they do come to you, listen to what they have to say. You may not understand, but accepting that they are having difficulties is the first step to show you care.
Think about things you struggled with when you were their age.
text:
Day 22 of mental health tips

Encourage communication. Let your child know that they can talk to you about their thoughts, feelings, or difficult situations they’re dealing with.
When they do come to you, listen to what they have to say. You may not understand, but accepting that they are having difficulties is the first step to show you care.
Think about things you struggled with when you were their age.

post_text:
Day 21 of mental health tips

Try to redirect or coach people in private. Adults don’t like our boss calling us out in front of our coworkers. Youth don’t like being corrected in front of their friends.

Set limits. Learn that it is OK to say no to things that will cause you too much stress.

Limit how long you talk to a person who is in distress. Use short direct sentences to show you care.
text:
Day 21 of mental health tips

Try to redirect or coach people in private. Adults don’t like our boss calling us out in front of our coworkers. Youth don’t like being corrected in front of their friends.

Set limits. Learn that it is OK to say no to things that will cause you too much stress.

Limit how long you talk to a person who is in distress. Use short direct sentences to show you care.

post_text:
Day 20 of mental health tips

When someone hurts your feelings, you can try these sentence stems
Please stop doing…...
I don’t like it when you…..
I feel sad when you…..
That makes me angry……
I’m upset because…

Putting your needs into words can give you a better sense of control over a problem.
Try phrases like:

*Can you use a softer voice when talking
*I like that you made your bed this morning
*Great job stopping when I asked you to

post_text:
Day 19 of mental health tips

Focus on what you want to see or hear from your loved ones. The more you look for something, the more you find it.
Family conversations are a great way to make connections and check in with each other. It allows family members to develop perspectives, family culture, respect for each other and problem-solving skills.

Use Conversation Starters for Families list questions to help get you and your family started on this activity.
Conversation Starters for Families
https://iowacore.gov/sites/default/files/accountable_talk_conversation_starter_cards.pdf

post_text:
Day 18 of mental health tips

Role-play situations that seem to trigger arguments. If you try using role-play, you might find that people are more calm, and you get solutions that work!

Creating new skills for children to access will be helpful when an adults is not present to support decision making

Replace yelling and criticizing with teachable moments. Did something bad or good just happen? Are they asking lots of questions and seem interested? This could be a great teachable moment.

Day 17 of mental health tips

Encourage a growth mindset by introducing a belief that you can find the positive angle when overwhelmed.
When frustrated about staying home- change your thoughts to when I’m home i am safe.
Remind them that you are always there if they need to talk or share with you.

post_text:
Day 16 of mental health tips

Routines help us to feel safe when things seem uncertain. Try to schedule activities at the same time everyday.

Using a posted visual schedule will create fairness, predictability within your household.

Help them engage in problem solving strategies: if the schedule needs to change.

*if you want to watch a specific show then what do we need to get done first

post_text:
Day 15 of mental health tips

Model and practice how to compromise. Meet in the middle, practice maintaining responsibilities while understanding what others need to do to feel safe.

Large amounts of time will be spent together in close proximity. Use language like, “ If you go first this time, I can go first next time; ….Visually keep track of it somewhere so, no one forgets.

If you make a mistake it’s okay to apologize. This will assist with the child accepting and being able to move on, but it will also teach them to accept their choices

post_text:
Day 14 of mental health tips

Follow through on the rules or boundaries you have set. If you don’t, people may think they have permission to ignore your rules or boundaries.

Keeping rules and boundaries in place keeps us safe and lets everyone know what is expected from each other.

Understanding how your action affect other;
Practice acknowledging commonalities with another person and send positive wishes to that person
Loving-Kindness for Someone You Care About

post_text:
Day 13 of mental health tips

Allow time for your child to ask questions about what is going on around them. Clarity of mind will mitigate the anxiety.

Listening is a really important life skill for parents. When your child feels listened to, they will feel like you understand them. Share with your child some of the many reasons you love them, then give them the opportunity to share the same about you

Here are the steps to listen actively to your child. The link will tell you how.
Simple Guide to Active Listening for Parents/Guardians

post_text:
As we celebrate National Nurse Week throughout the nation, today is officially National School Nurse Day!

National School Nurse Day was established in 1972 to foster a better understanding of the role of school nurses in the educational setting.

The theme for 2020 – School Nurses: Supporting Students in Times of Crisis – reinforces the changing times as this year, more than ever, all members of our school communities, school nurses included, have been required to take on unprecedented roles and adapt quickly to changes in their jobs. It is reflective of the significant roles school nurses have in the health care of their school communities to help make a healthier place for children and families to learn and grow during this crisis.

Thank you, Sheldon ISD nurses and nursing staff, for continuing to look out for the health and safety of our students!

post_text:
Day 12 of mental health tips

Try to be calm when someone acts out. If someone is genuinely overwhelmed, they may say and do things they do not mean.

If that happens, calm yourself first. Ask your loved one to take a break from what is overwhelming them

If you have children, Play with your kids and/or pets. Try and be creative by cooking something new or making something that will bring you a sense of accomplishment. Taking time to play, gives everyone a break from the stress of the moment, and a chance to connect with each other.

Cooking with Kids
https://youtu.be/DqhqIfHww7g

post_text:
Day 11 of mental health tips

Provide choices and allow a reasonable amount of time to make the choice.
People will need to have some basis in control, especially when they feel like things are beyond their understanding.

Use “I” statements to help the person know that you are sharing your feelings, not blaming the other person for their actions::

You can say:
*I feel hurt by the words that you are using.
*I am here to support you.

post_text:
Day 10 of mental health tips

Try to be patient. Just because someone can do something one time, doesn’t mean they can do it every time.

Know that it is okay to say “I don’t know” when you don’t know (even if the person asking you is a child). Over time, it can actually help people connect with you and trust you more.
Before getting angry:

Walk the person through what the end goal should look like.

post_text:
Day 9 of mental health tips

Try to avoid a power struggle. If you feel like you are in a tug-of-war, or constantly butting heads with someone, you’re probably in a power struggle. ”

Plan your responses to avoid an emotional reaction. If you’ve had the conflict a few times before, you probably know how it will start. Plan ahead, so you are better in control of what you say and do.

Try taking a break from the argument, or asking something like “how can get something that will work for both of us?

May 1 is also School Lunch Hero Day, dedicated to those men and women who make our school cafeterias a better place to be!

For many children, the cafeteria is the first place they enter on a school day. From the first time through the cafeteria line, the lunch hero has more than nutrition on their minds. The well-being of every child is important to them. Keeping them safe, happy, and providing them with good and delicious food is also a priority.

Often they see entire families grow up, and sometimes, they are family.

Thank you, Sheldon ISD Child Nutrition employees!

post_text:
Day 8 of mental health tips

Be as consistent as you can with your routines. If you want people to wash their hands before they eat, wash your hands every time before you eat.
Leading by example empowers us all.
Turn off the news & social media. Talk with someone (phone, video chat, in person). Taking a break from the worry of the world. Can help you feel better. Connecting with someone you know (even if it’s just on the phone) can help.

Try “sound bathing.” It is playing music with repetition of sounds that soothes your thoughts patterns
Benefits are:
*reduces stress and anxiety
*decrease blood pressure
*helps tun out your thoughts and increases balanced and focused thoughts

https://youtu.be/Nv07q-SFgNc

post_text:
Day 7 of mental health tips

Try First, Then: “First, clean up. Then, you can get on your phone.” Sometimes just saying “no” can make things worse. “First, Then” gives someone the chance to get something they want after something that needs to happen.

Write down how you feel. Just the simple act of writing down your feelings can help you feel better. Yes, it really is different than just sitting down and thinking about things.

Really don’t like writing? Keep a Bullet Journal.Try drawing, or doodling how you feel. It might sound odd if you’ve never tried it but it helps for a lot of people.

Exploring Feelings Using Journals:
https://www.pbs.org/video/adventures-learning-exploring-feelings/
text:
Day 7 of mental health tips

Try First, Then: “First, clean up. Then, you can get on your phone.” Sometimes just saying “no” can make things worse. “First, Then” gives someone the chance to get something they want after something that needs to happen.

Write down how you feel. Just the simple act of writing down your feelings can help you feel better. Yes, it really is different than just sitting down and thinking about things.

Really don’t like writing? Keep a Bullet Journal.Try drawing, or doodling how you feel. It might sound odd if you’ve never tried it but it helps for a lot of people.

Exploring Feelings Using Journals:
https://www.pbs.org/video/adventures-learning-exploring-feelings/

post_text:
Day 6 of mental health tips

Model what you expect. If you want people to use kind words, use kind words yourself. If you want someone to clean their space, clean your space. When saying what you want, talk in low, measured tones and volume.

Know that it is normal to feel stressed when so much is changing in the world around you. Knowing that you are not alone, can make things easier to live with.
Use paper to write examples of kind words on it.

*Allow yourself to draw activities or symbols that represent the word you wrote.
*Place the words around so you can see them.

post_text:
Day 5 of mental health tips

Avoid making last minute demands of people when they are in distress

Practice calmly talking through problems by using descriptive statements like;
~ I see your eyes are furrowed and that tells me you're upset.

~When you talk quickly that signals that you are worried about something.
Grounding exercises to use are naming:
*name 5 things you can see
*4 things you can hear
*3 things you can feel
*2 things you can smell
*1 thing you can taste

Visit Daily Calm Be Present
https://youtu.be/ZToicYcHIOU

post_text:
Day 4 on mental health tips

When people are upset, use simple vocabulary / words. Make simple statements, or ask a question. Allow time for the person to process your request.

Break down big problems into smaller parts. Take things one step at a time. Instead of trying to fix everything that is wrong right now, start by working on one thing you can do. *Make a schedule of activities: choose one thing you will do to take care of yourself

Vist Daily Calm Letting Go
https://youtu.be/syx3a1_LeFo

post_text:
Day 3 of mental health tips

Feelings (emotions) are a part of human nature. They give us information about what we’re experiencing and help us know how to react.

Instead of saying “Calm down,” say “I see you’re upset,” or “it makes sense that you’re angry.”
In order to handle difficult or challenging situations, it is important that both children and adults learn to recognize their emotions, understand that all people have emotions, and learn to manage their emotions.
Understanding Feelings lists several activities that will allow practice skills for recognizing and managing emotions

Understanding Your Feelings Activities--https://bit.ly/3bIpMSY

Students will need to turn in all school-owned instruments, concert apparel, and all other school-owned equipment next Monday, April 27; or Wednesday, April 29. The high school and both middle school campuses will be open for this check-in process from 10 a.m. to 6 p.m. on Monday; and again on Wednesday from 7 a.m. to 9 a.m. or 4 p.m. to 6 p.m.

In addition, information will be emailed to the each students’ Gmail Apps account with specific information for each campus. Please contact your child’s band director for additional information, if needed.

Remote Learning Update:
*Students are not required to complete their work during the day; students may work whenever it is convenient for the family.
*If you experience difficulty logging onto any of the online programs and feel like you are falling behind on assignments, please notify your child's teacher.
We are here for you. Remember, with the grading guidelines, if your 3rd 9-weeks average is higher than the average of your 3rd and 4th 9-weeks, your average will default to the 3rd 9-weeks average. Again, we are here for you. If you need support or have additional questions, please contact your teacher or campus administrator.

post_text:
Sheldon ISD celebrates 'After-School Appreciation Week'

Sheldon ISD joins school districts throughout the nation in celebrating After School Professionals Week (April 20-24).

Afterschool Professionals are skilled individuals who work with children and youth in diverse school and community-based settings to provide a wide variety of positive developmental relationships and experiences during out-of-school hours.

Currently in the U.S., an estimated 850,000 individuals are practicing members of the afterschool profession.

An estimated 10.2 million children participate in afterschool programs each year, and for every child in an afterschool program there are two more waiting to get in. Every young person deserves quality afterschool experiences that positively impact their development.

It takes skilled professionals to create these experiences. Because of the important role afterschool professionals play in the lives of kids, they deserve recognition and support!

post_text:
Curbside Meal Pickup Changes to Twice Per Week Beginning Monday, April 20

Dear Sheldon ISD Community,

In an ongoing effort to keep our students, staff and parents as safe as possible, Sheldon ISD will be limiting its curbside meal pickups to twice per week beginning on Monday, April 20.

Again, beginning on Monday, both breakfast and lunches may be picked up on Mondays and Wednesdays only from 9 a.m. to 11 a.m. for children ages 1-18 at the same five campus locations: Carroll Elementary, Royalwood Elementary, Sheldon Elementary, Null Middle School, and C. E. King Middle School.

At the time of pickup, Monday’s meal distributions will include enough food to last until Wednesday; and Wednesday’s meal distributions will cover meals through Friday.

Thank you – and let’s remain #SHELDONSTRONG!
text:
Curbside Meal Pickup Changes to Twice Per Week Beginning Monday, April 20

Dear Sheldon ISD Community,

In an ongoing effort to keep our students, staff and parents as safe as possible, Sheldon ISD will be limiting its curbside meal pickups to twice per week beginning on Monday, April 20.

Again, beginning on Monday, both breakfast and lunches may be picked up on Mondays and Wednesdays only from 9 a.m. to 11 a.m. for children ages 1-18 at the same five campus locations: Carroll Elementary, Royalwood Elementary, Sheldon Elementary, Null Middle School, and C. E. King Middle School.

At the time of pickup, Monday’s meal distributions will include enough food to last until Wednesday; and Wednesday’s meal distributions will cover meals through Friday.

Thank you – and let’s remain #SHELDONSTRONG!

Attention, C. E. King High School Seniors!

post_text:
Sheldon ISD Superintendent Dr. King Davis visited curbside meal pickup locations earlier today at Carroll Elementary, Royalwood Elementary, Sheldon Elementary, Null Middle School, and C. E. King Middle School.

We would like to publically recognize our hard-working child nutrition employees for helping make sure our students get fed each weekday during our temporary closure – and we are blessed to have them as part of our Sheldon ISD family. Since March 15, our child nutrition department has provided more than 40,000 meals to children ages 1-18 as part of the district’s “Grab-and-Go” curbside meal program.

Also, thank you to our other support staff for continuing to keep our facilities clean, landscaped, and operational during this unprecedented time.

Lastly, Sheldon ISD would like to wish everyone a Happy Easter – and please continue to stay #SHELDONSTRONG!

post_text:
Sheldon ISD to host 'Virtual Job Fair'

Sheldon ISD is hosting a "Virtual Job Fair" with interviews to be conducted virtually in the safety and comfort of your own home.

Interview dates will be Monday, April 20 - Friday, May 1.

Principals and Hiring Supervisors will be contacting candidates to schedule their virtual interviews. Therefore, it is important to please provide accurate phone numbers and email addresses.

Also, individuals who currently registered for this year's Job Fair prior to the district's closure will be notified about the new virtual format.

To apply for a virtual interview, please visit https://sheldontx.tedk12.com/hire/index.aspx

MORE INFO. - PLEASE VISIT THE SISD PERSONNEL SERVICES WEBPAGE
https://www.sheldonisd.com/apps/pages/index.jsp?uREC_ID=1368023&type=d&pREC_ID=1664275

post_text:
"Stay Well, Texas"

Cover your mouth and nose with a cloth face cover when around others

You could spread COVID-19 to others even if you do not feel sick.

Everyone should wear a cloth face cover when they have to go out in public, for example to the grocery store or to pick up other necessities.

Cloth face coverings should not be placed on young children under age 2, anyone who has trouble breathing, or is unconscious, incapacitated or otherwise unable to remove the mask without assistance.

The cloth face cover is meant to protect other people in case you are infected.

Do NOT use a facemask meant for a healthcare worker.
Continue to keep about 6 feet between yourself and others. The cloth face cover is not a substitute for social distancing.

For more information, please visit https://www.cdc.gov

- Shortness of breath

UPDATE Wednesday 12:00 P.M.
We were made aware that they are not handing out food. We apologize, as we were not told that they would not be handing out food today. Again, we apologize.

This Wednesday (April 1st) there will be a food distribution at 444 Maxey Rd Houston Texas. Families can come and pick up food at 11:30 a.m. They will have enough food for 250 families. It is drive up and no contact. Families will be asked to pop their trunk. The food will be put in and they can drive off.

post_text: Remote learning update... with the high number of students at the middle and high schools, it is taking us a bit longer to contact all parents. We will need to extend the expected time of parent communication. You should hear from your child's teacher in the coming days. Our network is down and we don't have access to our student files to send mass communication to parents. In the meantime, if your student remembers their student ID number, you may follow the directions attached to access the program. We appreciate your patience. Again, we will get through this because we are #SheldonStrong

post_text:
Dear Sheldon ISD Families and Community Members:

Sheldon ISD administrators are continuing to work closely with health experts this week in order to receive the most up-to-date information about the latest developments regarding the coronavirus (COVID-19).

On Friday, March 13, the district plans on sending a school notification call out (as well as posting the same information on the district’s website and social media pages) that will include important process changes as we prepare to return from Spring Break on Monday, March 16.

For additional information about the coronavirus, including education and prevention, please visit the Harris County Public Health Department’s website at http://publichealth.harriscountytx.gov or the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC) at https://www.cdc.gov.

On Friday, March 13, the district plans on sending a school notification call out (as well as posting the same information on the district’s website and social media pages) that will include important process changes as we prepare to return from Spring Break on Monday, March 16.

For additional information about the coronavirus, including education and prevention, please visit the Harris County Public Health Department’s website at http://publichealth.harriscountytx.gov or the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC) at https://www.cdc.gov.

Sheldon ISD conducted its first of two scheduled Town Hall meetings last night in the new C. E. King High School Auditorium. Superintendent Dr. King Davis explained the Sheldon ISD Bond 2020 initiatives - as well as answered various questions from the audience toward the end of the video.

For those who could not make last night's meeting, a second opportunity is scheduled for Saturday, March 21, at 10 a.m.

If you have any questions regarding the Bond 2020 initiatives, please email us at communications@sheldonisd.com.

Thank you.

Additional information may be found at www.sheldonisd.com/bond2020/

post_text:
2/27/20 | 9:30 p.m.
Breaking News - Sheldon ISD closes campuses, district offices for Friday, Feb. 28

One of the main waterline breaks that ruptured earlier today near the downtown Houston area has impacted portions of the Sheldon community.
Following a conference call with city officials tonight, it was determined that many of our students and families are being impacted by these water issues. Sheldon ISD administrators have decided to close all campuses and district offices on Friday, Feb. 28, including all after-school activities.
According to information from city officials, we are aware of the following communities that have been affected by the water boil notice: Edgewood Village; Parkway Mobile Home Estates; portions of Ralston Acres along Ticonderoga, John Ralston Road and Robert E. Lee Road; Beaumont Place; Liberty Lakes; Hampton Oaks; and Greensbrook/Kings Lake.

post_text:
KHS senior named ‘Regional Finalist’ for Coca-Cola scholarship

C. E. King High School senior Sofia Bucio-Garcia has been named a Regional Finalist for the Coca-Cola Scholarship. There were more than 93,000 applicants who applied for this scholarship – and Sofia’s next step is to participate in an interview. Then, if selected to move on, approximately 150 students will be invited to the Coca-Cola headquarters in Atlanta, Georgia to attend workshops and to receive their awards.

There were more than 93,000 applicants who applied for this scholarship – and Sofia’s next step is to participate in an interview. Then, if selected to move on, approximately 150 students will be invited to the Coca-Cola headquarters in Atlanta, Georgia to attend workshops and to receive their awards.

This year, 11 students will have their artwork shown at the Houston Livestock and Rodeo – which is a Sheldon ISD record!

This includes four “Best of Show” winners – including two in the high school division; one in the junior high division; and one in the elementary division. Also, we had five “Gold Medal” winners; and two “Special Merit” recipients.

Thank you also to our art instructors whose students placed: Leslie Roades (C. E. King High School), Jessica Little (C. E. King High School), Quentin Cleaves (Null Middle School), Alexandra Quevedo (Royalwood Elementary), and Natalie Leger (Sheldon Lake Elementary).

post_text:
KASE hosts College Mini Fair

On Friday, Feb 4, KASE hosted its annual mini college fair. Several schools participated including San Jacinto College-North, San Jacinto College-Maritime Campus, Lee College, the University of Houston-Downtown, Texas State Technical College, Texas Barber College, and the Texas Workforce Commission.

Additionally, Mike Guidry from the Texas A&M Agrilife Extension showcased “The Distracted Driving Simulator” which gave students a hands-on experience with the dangers of distracted driving – especially texting and driving.

According to Texas Department of Transportation data from 2012, distracted driving is responsible for up to 22% of the crashes in Texas – and teens have the highest rate of fatal crashes due to distracted driving.

Mayor Sylvester Turner’s Hire Houston Youth (HHY) program promotes large companies and other organizations to hire Houston youth (ages 16-24) during the summer in order to help provide workforce-readiness skills as well as engaging them with positive activities during the summer.

Please see the attached flyers for more information, including the Hire Houston Youth application.

Employers are also signing on with jobs, internships, and apprenticeships for year-round opportunities. For example, the City of Houston is hosting 450 interns during the summer.

post_text:
Congratulations to Sheldon FFA member Samantha Doerr, who caught a calf during the 2020 Fort Worth Stock Show & Rodeo’s Calf Scramble, earning a $500 purchase certificate for a show heifer and the chance for up to $16,000 in scholarship awards.
The certificate, presented by Stock Show Calf Scramble Committee Chairman, Paxton Motheral, was sponsored by Doug and Betty Wolf, in memory of Lois Luig.
Doerr’s parents are Michael Doerr and Angela McGehee.
Samantha will use the purchase certificate toward the cost of a heifer for a 4-H or FFA project that she will raise and exhibit at next year’s Forth Worth Stock Show & Rodeo.

post_text:
February is Black History Month - and this year's national theme is "African Americans and the Vote."

Through voting-rights campaigns and legal suits from the turn of the twentieth century to the mid-1960s, African Americans made their voices heard as to the importance of the vote.

Indeed the fight for black voting rights continues in the courts today.

More information: https://asalh.org/black-history-themes/

The University Interscholastic League (UIL) released its realignments this morning and, although C. E. King High School remains in District 21, most of its district opponents have changed.

UIL - Class 6A, Region 3, District 21
C. E. King
Beaumont Westbrook
North Shore
Humble
Humble Atascocita
Humble Kingwood
Humble Summer Creek

The top four teams will advance to the playoffs in each sport. This new realignment will not go into effect until the beginning of the 2020-2021 school year.

Congratulations to Haley Staten of King Middle School for winning today's 2020 Sheldon ISD Spelling Bee. Eli Chavez, Sheldon Lake Elementary, placed second; and Luis Cano of Null Middle School finished third.

Also, congratulations to all Sheldon ISD participants - as this year's event lasted 20 rounds!

Staten now advances to compete in the 2020 Houston Media Spelling Bee Feb. 29 at the Baylor College of Medicine Academy at Houston ISD's Ryan Middle School.

Pictured (from left) are Haley Staten, first place winner; Eli Chavez, second place; and Luis Cano, third place.

January 27 at 6:37 PM ·

Members of the Sheldon ISD Superintendent's Advisory Council met on Jan. 24 in the Ney Administration Building Boardroom.

The Superintendent's Student Advisory Council is comprised of Sheldon ISD elementary, middle and high school students who focus on continuous improvement and supporting all schools through the lens of equality.

Together with Sheldon ISD Superintendent Dr. King Davis, these students will work to deliver on the commitments outlined in the Sheldon ISD Strategic Plan as well as to Connect, Empower, Value and Achieve.

#whysheldonisd

Application Deadlines: Jan. 29, 2020 - Feb. 11, 2020

Parents of Eighth Graders,
If your student is interested in applying to Sheldon Early College High School or the KNIT (King Nurses in Training) program, don’t miss the deadline to apply. Applications will be available for students to pick up at each middle school beginning on January 29. Students should complete the application and submit it to their middle school counselor no later than 4 PM on February 11.

Link to application online: https://www.sheldonisd.com/apps/pages/index.jsp?uREC_ID=1353416&type=d&pREC_ID=1828593

shared_text:
Sheldon ISD added 25 new photos.
January 7 at 11:33 AM ·

It was estimated that between 1,000-1,200 individuals from in and around the Sheldon community came out Monday evening to celebrate the official ribbon cutting ceremony for the new C. E. King High School.
Sheldon ISD Superintendent Dr. King Davis thanked those in attendance, as well current and past Sheldon ISD school board members, for helping make this dream a reality following a May 2016 bond election where more than 70 percent of voters approved a $285 million bond package that included Sheldon Lake Elementary, Sheldon ISD Panther Stadium, and the new C. E. King High School.
Campus tours were also provided after Monday's brief program where community members had an opportunity to see this awesome new facility that was incorporated to drive 21st century learning.

Attention, C. E. King High School Parents/Guardians:

As a reminder, All C. E. King High School students are now considered eligible bus riders since students will be transitioning to the new KHS campus beginning Jan. 8, 2020.

Letters were sent home today with all KHS students explaining detailed information for any new bus riders who will now need district transportation to the new high school campus.

To electronically view bus information for your neighborhood – including bus numbers, route times and pick up locations, please use our “infofinder” web search tool at http://www.infofinderi.com/ifi/?cid=SI3VJE5UUY6

If you have additional questions or concerns, please call our Sheldon ISD Transportation Department at 281-727-1400.

Link to Sheldon ISD Transportation webpage: https://www.sheldonisd.com/apps/pages/index.jsp?uREC_ID=1369091&type=d&pREC_ID=1554274

post_text:
Sheldon ISD Panther Stadium Welcomes Denton Guyer and Spring Westfield Fans!

Sheldon ISD Panther Stadium is proud to host the Denton Guyer Wildcats (13-1) vs Spring Westfield Mustangs (13-1) Saturday, December 14, beginning at 1 p.m. in a Class 6A Division 2, State Semifinal football matchup.
Sheldon ISD Stadium is located at 11433C E. Sam Houston Pkwy North, Houston, Texas 77044.

TICKET INFORMATION
Tickets will be $10 each at the gate. Also, both teams are offering pre-game sales, but you must go through one of these high schools prior to Saturday's game in order to receive discount ticket prices.
UIL district and coaching passes will be accepted at this venue - as determined by both teams.

Gates will open at approximately 11:30 a.m.

HOME TEAM is Westfield
VISITING TEAM is Guyer

Dear Sheldon ISD Community members,

Although our two Town Hall meetings have concluded, we would like to extend the invitation to offer our community members an opportunity to take a brief, five-minute survey regarding facility needs and ongoing student growth throughout the district.

Here is a link to the survey: https://www.surveymonkey.com/r/2Q5QKP9

Also, we have a webpage dedicated to the Town Hall meetings – including videos in both English and Spanish. This page may be found at the following link: http://www.sheldonisd.com/townhall/

Please share this information with your friends and neighbors who live in our community. The deadline to take the survey is Wednesday, Dec. 11 by the end of the day.

Thank you in advance for your participation.

- Update on remaining tickets for Saturday's Class 6A, Division I State Quarterfinal Football Game at Sheldon ISD Panther Stadium -

Fans, as of 12/6/19 at 2 p.m., there are only 2,400 tickets remaining for Saturday’s playoff game. All tickets are $12 at the gate, and fans must purchase these tickets – and sit – on the home side of the stadium.

Also, please remember…no tailgating is allowed at Sheldon ISD Panther Stadium. We need all the spaces for vehicles to park at this game – thank you for your understanding.

post_text:
Sheldon ISD received a grant for our girls to attend the Girls STEM Academy at Space Center Houston for 5 days of lessons and activities from building and launching rockets on the Launchpad, researching rocketry and learning to fly drones and robotics. This program is designed to encourage middle -school girls to pursue STEM careers through hands-on activities that involve Science, Technology, Engineering and Math.

Girls in STEM today--Women in STEM tomorrow!

Check out this picture of the 7th grade STEM girls after completing their 13 hour STEM Academy at Space Center Houston where they learned about rocketry, flying drones and robotics. 50 girls attended (25 from KMS and NMS)

post_text: Sheldon ISD is so grateful for the Barbara Bush Houston Literacy Foundation partnership. This past weekend the leadership team from Royalwood Elementary and other volunteers from around the city helped organize books that would be donated to campuses throughout Houston. Overall, they helped organize and bag 27,000 books!

post_text:
Happy Veterans Day to all of the veterans!

Sheldon ISD would also like to thank the veterans in our district for their service! We are so grateful to have you be a part of the Sheldon ISD Family.

Sheldon ISD attended the North Channel Area Chamber of Commerce’s annual “Chamber Salutes” Luncheon and Expo honoring our veterans, law enforcement, and first responders. Here is a picture of the veterans who attended the event with our Executive Director of Personnel Services Kristi Amarantos and our Chief Administrative Officer Christie Gates.

post_text: The C.E. King High School Marching Band completed another spectacular competition season this year! The band was awarded 1st division for the fifth consecutive year at UIL competition and was awarded 3rd place in their class at the Gulf Coast Marching Band Championships at McNeese State University. Many thanks to all the parents, staff, and students who made these accomplishments possible!
text: The C.E. King High School Marching Band completed another spectacular competition season this year! The band was awarded 1st division for the fifth consecutive year at UIL competition and was awarded 3rd place in their class at the Gulf Coast Marching Band Championships at McNeese State University. Many thanks to all the parents, staff, and students who made these accomplishments possible!

post_text:
Sheldon ISD is at the Armenta’s Banquet Hall in Channelview to take part in the North Channel Area Chamber of Commerce’s annual “Chamber Salutes” Luncheon and Expo honoring our veterans, law enforcement, and first responders.
Pictured is Col. Peace, a United States Air Force Officer who currently teaches Civil Air Patrol at Null Middle School. Col. Peace has been with our district for the past 11 years.
Thank you, Col. Peace, for your service to our country - and to all of our active and former military (as well as to our law enforcement and first responders).

post_text:
11/6/19, 1:34 p.m.

Parents, Sheldon ISD Learning Center, Sheldon Early Childhood Academy and Sheldon Elementary have been placed on "Lockout" at the recommendation of Precinct 3 due to police activity in the area.
We will continue to keep you updated.
Thank you.

LOCKOUT DEFINITION:
- Exterior doors will be closed and locked
- Any personnel outside will be instructed to come inside immediately
- Continue to work as normal
- No entrance of exit until lockout is cleared

post_text:
Sheldon ISD would like to congratulate Londyn Davis, a Sheldon Lake Elementary third grader, for winning the 2019 Junior Olympics in the 100 meters and placing 5th in the 200 meters. This little runner is amazing! Her first title was at the age of 6 as the fastest 6 year old in Texas!

Congratulations Londyn! We are so proud of you!

post_text:
Sheldon ISD kicks off its Red Ribbon Week Campaign this week in conjunction with National Red Ribbon Week.
The purpose of Red Ribbon Week is to serve as a method and opportunity for communities and individuals to take a stand against drug abuse and to educate others on its destruction.
Also, it is the oldest and largest drug prevention campaign in the country.
This year’s National Red Ribbon Week theme is: Send a Message. Stay Drug Free.™

post_text: These are the rules and regulations for the upcoming football game. We will not allow umbrellas, firearms, air horns, purses, or backpacks for safety reasons. Each person is allowed to bring one bag that is clear no larger than 12 inches by 6 inches, similar to a Ziploc bag. The district will provide clear bags for those who attend that do not have one at the stadium. Also, from now on, there will be a line at the concession stands that is just for drinks. Please know that for the time being, we only accept cash for any and all purchases. See you at the game. Go panthers.

post_text:
Congratulations to the C.E. King High School Panther Marching Band for earning an overall Division I rating at Saturday's marching competition at Galena Park ISD Stadium. This was the fifth consecutive year the KHS marching band has earned a Division I rating.
Note: According to UIL regulations, Class 6A schools throughout the state do not advance this year in state competition.

post_text: Sheldon ISD was honored at the STEM Bridges Houston Your Pathway to College & Beyond Gala and Awards Ceremony on Oct. 12 as the district was the recipient of the STEM Program Innovators of the Year award! Congratulations to Becky Zalesnik, Annette Clark, Anike Allen and all of our district STEM teachers for their contributions in helping our district achieve this prestigious honor!

post_text:
Sheldon ISD joins Texas public schools – as well as other school districts throughout the country – in celebrating National Principals Month.

Sheldon ISD principals include Dr. Denise Mustin, Cravens ECA; Joel Leal, Sheldon ECA; Christopher Dickson, Sheldon Lake Elementary; Dr. Rachelle Ysquierdo, Sheldon Elementary; Lorena Carrasco, Royalwood Elementary; Cheri Dixon, Monahan Elementary; Tacarra Williams, Garrett Elementary; Solmaria Benevides, Carroll Elementary; Raff Saeed C. E. King Middle School; Leroy Bradley, Null Middle School; Dr. Keith Brooks, C. E. King High School; and John McGee, KASE Academy.

Thank you – principals - for your daily leadership in fostering a positive climate and culture for your students and staff.

Sheldon ISD parents - are you finding it hard to manage some of your child’s behaviors now that school is back in session and your family gets into a new routine? Please see the attached newsletter developed with nearby Texas Children’s Pediatrics North Shore for tips on managing difficult behaviors as well as information on Attention Deficit Hyperactivity Disorder (ADHD). Please message if you have any questions or concerns.

https://www.sheldonisd.com/apps/news/article/1084242?fbclid=IwAR10zlY4t74Bg7Oo64al00Pjhh8nU5y1TWixSOoaX8ITHGyNkhh4a5q_yOI

Please know that for the time being, we only accept cash for any and all purchases. See you at the game. Go panthers.
text: There are the new rules and regulations for the upcoming football game. We will not allow umbrellas, firearms, air horns, purses, or backpacks for safety reasons. Each person is allowed to bring one bag that is clear no larger than 12 inches by 6 inches, similar to a Ziploc bag. The district will provide clear bags for those who attend that do not have one at the stadium. Also, from now on, there will be a line at the concession stands that is just for drinks. Please know that for the time being, we only accept cash for any and all purchases. See you at the game. Go panthers.

post_text:
Members of the Sheldon ISD Board of Trustees unanimously approved an order authorizing the issuance of $15.1 million in Sheldon ISD Unlimited Tax Refunded Bonds that will save the district more than $2.3 million in cash flow savings.

Abraham George, Sheldon ISD Chief Financial Officer, said this overall potential savings is a result of lower interest rates throughout the bond market.

“When these bonds go out for sale, they will be sold to the lowest bidder,” George said, “which is a win-win situation for our school district.”

George said he would also like to thank the district’s financial advisor, U. S. Capital Advisors; and bond counsel, Hunton, Andrews & Kurth, LLP for all of their hard work throughout this process.
text:

“When these bonds go out for sale, they will be sold to the lowest bidder,” George said, “which is a win-win situation for our school district.”

George said he would also like to thank the district’s financial advisor, U. S. Capital Advisors; and bond counsel, Hunton, Andrews & Kurth, LLP for all of their hard work throughout this process.

Sheldon ISD Executive Director for Student Services J. R. Webster received the “Distinguished Administrator Award” by the Texas Music Educators Association last night in a special ceremony at the SISD School Board meeting.
Webster, who was nominated by C. E. King Middle School band directors Crystal Hoisager and Brice Harkness, was recognized for his continued dedication and support for the fine arts. Over the past years, Webster has also been instrumental in preserving quality music education program throughout the district.
Pictured (from left) are J. R. Webster, Crystal Hoisager, and Brice Harkness.

post_text:
Sheldon ISD maintenance crews have been busy visiting campuses throughout the district assessing any potential water issues that resulted from Tropical Depression Imelda.

Workers discovered a few roof leaks that caused minimal damage to some ceiling tiles, which allowed a small amount of water to seep into the building. The water was quickly cleaned up and ceiling tiles are currently being replaced.

Currently, crews are busy cleaning the affected facilities at this time, and classes will resume as scheduled on Monday, Sept. 23.

post_text:
INFORMATION UPDATE - 9/17 | 5:42 P.M.

Sheldon ISD has joined other local school districts in and around the Harris County area by teaming up with the Harris County Flood Control District to make sound decisions as to whether or not have school on Wednesday due to projected heavy rainfall caused by Tropical Storm Imelda.

District administrators will take part in a phone conference at approximately 3 a.m. on Wednesday. A decision will be made about the school day by 4 a.m.

We will make you aware of our decision by providing you with a call out from our school notification system – as well as posting information on our district website, social media pages, and local news outlets.

Thank you, and please stay safe.
text:
INFORMATION UPDATE - 9/17 | 5:42 P.M.

Sheldon ISD has joined other local school districts in and around the Harris County area by teaming up with the Harris County Flood Control District to make sound decisions as to whether or not have school on Wednesday due to projected heavy rainfall caused by Tropical Storm Imelda.

District administrators will take part in a phone conference at approximately 3 a.m. on Wednesday. A decision will be made about the school day by 4 a.m.

We will make you aware of our decision by providing you with a call out from our school notification system – as well as posting information on our district website, social media pages, and local news outlets.

Thank you, and please stay safe.

post_text:
Happy National Hispanic Heritage Month - which runs today through Oct. 15!

During National Hispanic Heritage Month (September 15 to October 15) we recognize the contributions made and the important presence of Hispanic and Latino Americans to the United States and celebrate their heritage and culture.

Hispanics have had a profound and positive influence on our country through their strong commitment to family, faith, hard work, and service. They have enhanced and shaped our national character with centuries-old traditions that reflect the multiethnic and multicultural customs of their community.

post_text:
Students briefly evacuate NMS after fire alarm goes off earlier this afternoon

This afternoon, Null Middle School students were forced to briefly evacuate after a fire alarm went off. Please know all students were safe. The fire department immediately arrived on scene and determined there was no evidence of any fire in or around the campus. Students were able to re-enter the building once the fire department deemed it safe.

-----------------------------------

Esta tarde, los estudiantes de la Escuela Intermedia Null se vieron obligados a evacuar brevemente después de que sonó una alarma de incendio. Por favor sepa que todos los estudiantes estaban a salvo. El departamento de bomberos llegó inmediatamente a la escena y determinó que no había evidencia de ningún incendio dentro o alrededor del campus. Los estudiantes pudieron volver a la escuela cuando los bomberos dijeron que era serguo.
text:
Students briefly evacuate NMS after fire alarm goes off earlier this afternoon

This afternoon, Null Middle School students were forced to briefly evacuate after a fire alarm went off. Please know all students were safe. The fire department immediately arrived on scene and determined there was no evidence of any fire in or around the campus. Students were able to re-enter the building once the fire department deemed it safe.

-----------------------------------

Esta tarde, los estudiantes de la Escuela Intermedia Null se vieron obligados a evacuar brevemente después de que sonó una alarma de incendio. Por favor sepa que todos los estudiantes estaban a salvo. El departamento de bomberos llegó inmediatamente a la escena y determinó que no había evidencia de ningún incendio dentro o alrededor del campus. Los estudiantes pudieron volver a la escuela cuando los bomberos dijeron que era serguo.

Sheldon ISD parents are encouraged to complete a free-and-reduced meal application form to see if they qualify for their child to receive free or reduced meals throughout the 2019-20 school year.

There are two methods for applying:
(1) School Cafe (www.schoolcafe.com) is the best method
- This is a website (apps also available for Apple and Android devices)
- Fill out a free-and-reduced meal application for 2019-20
- View your child's meal balance
- Add money to your child's account
- And much more....

(2) Fill out a paper form and turn it in to your child's campus child nutrition manager

All of the information above may be found on the Sheldon ISD Child Nutrition page by following this link: https://www.sheldonisd.com/apps/pages/index.jsp?uREC_ID=1355600&type=d&pREC_ID=1755588

Important back-to-school information for Academic, ECHS, and MECA dual credit students

Academic, ECHS, and MECA dual credit students who have 7 AM classes at San Jacinto College can catch the Sheldon bus at one of three hubs--Sheldon Elementary, Null Middle School, or KHS (Annex) at 6:15 AM. The bus should arrive by 6:25 and take students directly to San Jac. The San Jac dual credit office and SISD personnel will be available at the college to assist students on the first day.

post_text:
Update on ExxonMobil fire in Baytown earlier today

We would like to provide you with an update on the ExxonMobil incident that occurred earlier today.

According to an article by CNN that was published on its website a few hours ago, the shelter-in-place advisory around the Baytown area was lifted earlier today after monitoring failed to detect "any levels of concern" in the air. Also, the fire had been contained by the evening.

Thank you for your patience and understanding today as district administrators continued to place the safety and security of our students and staff as their top priorities.

Although Sheldon ISD was never part of the initial shelter-in-place advisory that was issued this morning, administrators made a conscious decision to err on the side of caution by keeping students and staff indoors today.

When our students, coaches and athletes return tomorrow for their respected practices, workouts or rehearsals, they will be free to practice outside.

Thank you.

Thank you for your patience and understanding today as district administrators continued to place the safety and security of our students and staff as their top priorities.

Although Sheldon ISD was never part of the initial shelter-in-place advisory that was issued this morning, administrators made a conscious decision to err on the side of caution by keeping students and staff indoors today.

When our students, coaches and athletes return tomorrow for their respected practices, workouts or rehearsals, they will be free to practice outside.

Thank you.

post_text:
This is an important informational message regarding this morning’s Exxon fire in Baytown.

Although local authorities and emergency management personnel have not included the Sheldon ISD community among its shelter-in-place protocol - SISD administrators have decided to err on the side of caution and have all students and/or student athletes to come inside for any practices, rehearsals or other school-related activities that were scheduled today.

District officials will continue to monitor and evaluate these ongoing conditions in the Baytown area and will keep you informed regarding tomorrow’s scheduled activities.

Thank you.

Hi parents! Back-to-school is right around the corner.
Here are a few of the most popular questions we have been getting and a link where you can find more information.

post_text:
Sheldon ISD personnel have been continuously monitoring the progress of what has now been classified as Tropical Storm Barry.
As of noon today, Tropical Storm Barry was located about 90 miles southeast of the mouth of the Mississippi River with maximum sustained winds of 40 mph.
The storm was moving west at 5 mph.
Also, according to The Weather Channel, computer models have ruled out the likelihood of Barry severely impacting the Houston and surrounding areas. Although this is great news, please remember that these are merely weather forecast predictions. It was also reported that Barry will likely become a hurricane within the next 24 hours.
Please continue to take precautions as you plan for the weekend - and remember to stay safe!
#SHELDONSTRONG
In addition, please keep those families in the Mississippi and Louisiana areas in your thoughts and prayers.
On Wednesday, with the storm still out over the Gulf of Mexico, it dumped as much as 8 inches on metro New Orleans in just three hours.

post_text:
National Hurricane Center closely monitoring potential tropical depression in Gulf Coast

Posted 7/9/19, 9:36 a.m.

A low-pressure system over southwestern Georgia is expected to move over the Gulf of Mexico on Wednesday and has an 80 percent chance of developing into a tropical depression by the end of the week, the National Hurricane Center posted earlier today.

The hurricane center advised residents from the western Florida peninsula to the upper Texas coast to monitor the system as potential heavy rains and wind gusts are likely to impact coastal areas spanning from Florida to Texas.

It is also important to note that the hurricane center cautioned that the magnitude of potential wind or storm surge impacts along the Gulf Coast are too soon to be determined.

Photo Credit: CNN
text:
National Hurricane Center closely monitoring potential tropical depression in Gulf Coast

Posted 7/9/19, 9:36 a.m.

A low-pressure system over southwestern Georgia is expected to move over the Gulf of Mexico on Wednesday and has an 80 percent chance of developing into a tropical depression by the end of the week, the National Hurricane Center posted earlier today.

The hurricane center advised residents from the western Florida peninsula to the upper Texas coast to monitor the system as potential heavy rains and wind gusts are likely to impact coastal areas spanning from Florida to Texas.

It is also important to note that the hurricane center cautioned that the magnitude of potential wind or storm surge impacts along the Gulf Coast are too soon to be determined.

Photo Credit: CNN

post_text:
Approximately 30 students from Sheldon ISD had an opportunity to participate in a deep sea fishing trip on June 19 in conjunction with the Hook Spit Junior Angler Association as well as many generous corporate sponsors.

Students received an all expense paid deep sea fishing trip out of Galveston Island, t-shirts, lunch, drinks and snacks throughout the course of the day as well as fishing prizes and many other great opportunities.

Goals of the program:
• Provide a meaningful and enjoyable fishing opportunity to local youth;
• Promote fishing as an alternative leisure activity;
• Offer education elements such as angler ethics, fish ID and water safety; and
• Develop skills that provide a lifelong hobby.

Sheldon ISD's first-ever elementary volleyball league was a huge success as approximately 40 athletes participated in the three-month event.

Players learned the basics of how to play volleyball, team skills, and basic rules of the game. Our players at C. E. King high school that are in the volleyball program also helped coach the league.

Sheldon ISD Community, we are looking for technology volunteers to help our students. Check out the flyer and link for more information on how you can help!

The Microsoft Philanthropies TEALS Program (Technology Education and Literacy in Schools) supports computer science (CS) education by recruiting and training technology professionals to volunteer in high school classrooms. These volunteers are paired with CS teachers to help high schools in the Houston metro area and nationwide build and grow rigorous, sustainable CS programs.

https://www.sheldonisd.com/apps/news/article/1048340
